awd_titl_txt: Measuring Early Mathematical Reasoning Skills: Developing Tests of Numeric Relational Reasoning and Spatial Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
Numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning are critical to success in later mathematics coursework, including Algebra 1, a gatekeeper to success at the post-secondary level, and success in additional STEM domains, such as chemistry, geology, biology, and engineering. Given the importance of these skills for later success, it is imperative that there are high-quality screening tools available to identify students at-risk for difficulty in these areas. The primary aim of this study is to develop mathematics screening assessment tools for Grades K-2 over the course of four years that measure students' abilities in numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning. The team of researchers will develop Measures of Mathematical Reasoning Skills system, which will contain Tests of Numeric Relational Reasoning (T-NRR) and Tests of Spatial Reasoning (T-SR). The measures will be intended for use by teachers and school systems to screen students to determine who is at-risk for difficulty in early mathematics, including students with disabilities. The measures will help provide important information about the intensity of support that may be needed for a given student. Three forms per grade level will be developed for both the T-NRR and T-SR with accompanying validity and reliability evidence collected. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The development of the T-NRR and T-SR measures will follow an iterative process across five phases. The phases include (1) refining the construct; (2) developing test specifications and item models; (3) developing items; (4) field testing the items; and (5) conducting validity studies. The evidence collected and evaluated during each phase will contribute to the overall evaluation of the reliability of the measures and the validity of the interpretations made using the measures. Item models, test specifications, and item development will be continuously evaluated and refined based on data from cognitive interviews, field tests, and reviews by mathematics educators, teachers of struggling students, teachers of culturally and linguistically diverse populations, and a Technical Advisory Board. In the final phase of development of the T-NRR and T-SR, reliability of the results will be estimated and multiple sources of validity evidence will be collected to examine the concurrent and predictive relation with other criterion measures, classification accuracy, and sensitivity to growth.  Approximately 4,500 students in Grades K-2 will be involved in all phases of the research including field tests and cognitive interviews. Data will be analyzed using a two-parameter IRT model to ensure item and test form comparability.

por.por_cntn:
The primary aim of the MMaRS project was to develop high-quality assessment tools for teachers in Kindergarten through Grade 2. The purpose of these assessments was to provide instructionally-relevant information about two highly predictive early mathematics constructs: numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning. 

To support the instructional relevance of these assessments, we grounded the content in the science of how people learn. We articulated learning progressions for each construct that identify how children develop and extend their understanding of numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning within and across grades. These learning progressions were articulated through a systematic process that involved conducting a thorough review of the literature and consulting with national and internationally renowned experts. We specified the fine-grained knowledge, skills, and cognitive processes (subsequently referred to as subcomponents) students engage in to develop proficiency in numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning. 

To gather empirical evidence about the validity of the learning progressions, we conducted cognitive interviews with children in Kindergarten through Grade 3. Cognitive interviews are a form of task-based interviews that are designed to elicit participants’ cognitive processes to provide insights into how they store and structure their knowledge in long-term memory. We used these data to verify whether we had sufficiently specified the learning progressions for numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning. In addition, we surveyed Kindergarten through Grade 3 teachers to better understand their instructional focus on these constructs. We asked about their perception of the developmental appropriateness and proposed ordering of thesubcomponents within the learning progressions, as well as the emphasis they placed on teaching the knowledge and skills specified in the learning progressions. Findings from the cognitive interviews and surveys were presented to a panel of experts to help us iteratively refine the learning progressions. As a result of this process, we concluded that the learning progressions had substantial evidence to verify that they accurately represent students’ development of proficiency in numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning over time.  

Using the finalized learning progressions as the content for the MMaRS assessments, we designed item models for each subcomponent. An item model is a template that serves as the basis for future item development efforts. We drafted at least two item models for each subcomponent across Kindergarten through Grade 2. We designed the item models to be maximally accessible and generate accurate and reliable information. The item models varied by key features such as the response mode, use of manipulatives, and visual presentation.  

Next, we tested the item models with students in Kindergarten through Grade 2 using think aloud interviews. Think aloud interviews are a form of task-based interview that probe students’ thinking and problem-solving processes as they are responding to an item (concurrent) and/or immediately after generating a response(retrospective). We conducted think aloud interviews to examine the alignment between the knowledge, skills, and cognitive processes we were intending to measure and those that were actually elicited by students as they responded to the items. We used both concurrent think aloud and retrospective think aloud techniques forthe MMaRS assessment items. Students’ responses were analyzed to determine which aspects of the item models generated the most accurate and meaningful information about students’ understanding of numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning.  

Prior to finalizing the items, we conducted an external review with experts in early childhood mathematics. These experts rated each item for alignment to the targeted subcomponent of the learning progression, as well as the accessibility of the language, accuracy of the mathematical representations, and potential sources of bias. These data were systematically analyzed and used to make final revisions to the items. We conducted additional think aloud interviews for all item that were changed significantly based on feedback from the external reviewers. As a result, we generated items that were theoretically and empirically aligned to the numeric relational reasoning and spatial reasoning learning progressions.  

Because the MMaRS assessments are designed to support teachers’ instructional decision making, it was important to develop resources that enable teachers to administer and use the assessments. To meet this goal, we formed a teacher advisory panel to provide ongoing and iterative feedback about the design and development of the MMaRS assessment resources. We solicited their input on the design of the technology-enabled testing interface and the accompanying student materials. Moreover, using human-centered design methodology, we co-created a decision-making guide to support teachers’ understanding and use of the MMaRS assessments. This approach allowed us to rapidly create prototypes with teachers to address their feedback in real-time. To evaluate whether these MMaRS assessment resources were interpretable by other teachers, we conducted think aloud interviews with a new sample of teachers. Data were examined to determine the usability and usefulness of the resources. Final adjustments were made to support teachers’ engagement with the MMaRS assessment resource.
